articles.headline: G.O.P. Edge as Dynamics Shift in House Races
articles.snippet: With no partisan surge this year, the overall dynamic favors Republicans, who look poised to maintain their hold on the House.
articles.abstract: With no partisan surge this year, the overall dynamic favors Republicans, who look poised to maintain their hold on the House.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Since 2006, members of the House have faced electoral waves that swept away scores of incumbents.

articles.headline: Europe’s Auto Industry Has Reached Day of Reckoning
articles.snippet: A dreadful year for European car sales may force the region’s industry to deal with the overstaffed, underused factories that have been undermining earnings for years.
articles.abstract: A dreadful year for European car sales may force the region’s industry to deal with the overstaffed, underused factories that have been undermining earnings for years.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — For European carmakers, the day of reckoning may finally be at hand.
articles.byline: By Jack Ewing and Bill Vlasic

articles.headline: A Global Steel Giant Scales Back
articles.snippet: ArcelorMittal, which flourished as the largest steelmaker during the global economic boom, is now suffering the effects of a European and worldwide slowdown.
articles.abstract: ArcelorMittal, which flourished as the largest steelmaker during the global economic boom, is now suffering the effects of a European and worldwide slowdown.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Steel is a notoriously volatile industry. But four years ago, Lakshmi Mittal, the Indian-born tycoon, appeared to have mastered the business.

articles.headline: The News Isn’t Good for Zynga, Maker of FarmVille
articles.snippet: A shortfall in revenue and a weak outlook sent the social game developer’s stock plunging by nearly 40 percent on Wednesday. The news was seen as boding ill for Facebook.
articles.abstract: A shortfall in revenue and a weak outlook sent the social game developer’s stock plunging by nearly 40 percent on Wednesday. The news was seen as boding ill for Facebook.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The social games developer Zynga is withering faster than neglected corn on its signature hit FarmVille.
articles.byline: By David Streitfeld and Jenna Wortham

articles.headline: Negative Ads Hit at Identity to Shape Race for Presidency
articles.snippet: President Obama and Mitt Romney, who can have trouble connecting with voters on a personal level, are trying to define each other as detached from mainstream American life.
articles.abstract: President Obama and Mitt Romney, who can have trouble connecting with voters on a personal level, are trying to define each other as detached from mainstream American life.
articles.lead_paragraph: RICHMOND, Va. — The man looks incredulous, his voice rising in exasperation as he tells President Obama to stop demonizing small-business owners. “We need somebody who believes in America,” he says, right before viewers hear, “I’m Mitt Romney, and I approved this message.”

articles.headline: Fed Sees Both Benefits and Risks in New Moves
articles.snippet: The Federal Reserve is weighing its options as economic growth remains sluggish.
articles.abstract: The Federal Reserve is weighing its options as economic growth remains sluggish.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The argument for the Federal Reserve to introduce another round of stimulus, and its reasons for hesitation, can both be summarized by a single number: 3.53 percent, the average interest rate last week on a 30-year mortgage.

articles.headline: Retailers’ Idea: Think Smaller in Urban Push
articles.snippet: With little room to expand in the suburbs, retailers like Office Depot, Wal-Mart and Target have aimed their expansion plans at cities, overhauling store sizes, packages and signs.
articles.abstract: With little room to expand in the suburbs, retailers like Office Depot, Wal-Mart and Target have aimed their expansion plans at cities, overhauling store sizes, packages and signs.
articles.lead_paragraph: As young Americans move to cities, retailers that grew up in the suburbs are following them. And unlike previous efforts, they are doing it the cities’ way.

articles.headline: China Casts Ex-Leader’s Wife in a Familiar Role
articles.snippet: In formally accusing her in a poisoning death, the government put Gu Kailai in a well-worn Chinese framework: the conniving vixen whose greed derailed her husband’s career.
articles.abstract: In formally accusing her in a poisoning death, the government put Gu Kailai in a well-worn Chinese framework: the conniving vixen whose greed derailed her husband’s career.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — In a nation that prefers the wives of political leaders to be bland adornments, Gu Kailai was positively fluorescent. Married to Bo Xilai, the Politburo member whose downfall earlier this year is still shaking the Communist Party, she reveled in her brash, ambitious ways.

articles.headline: Assurances on Euro by Central Bank Chief Lift Stocks
articles.snippet: Markets and the euro rose after Mario Draghi told a conference in London that the central bank was prepared to “do whatever it takes to preserve” the currency.
articles.abstract: Markets and the euro rose after Mario Draghi told a conference in London that the central bank was prepared to “do whatever it takes to preserve” the currency.
articles.lead_paragraph: The head of the European Central Bank said on Thursday that policy makers would do “whatever it takes” to save the euro zone, buoying global financial markets.
